content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2002" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts. SEC. 2. INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS AUTHORIZED. The prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits is repealed, with amendments to various acts. Effective date is after a 2-year period from enactment. SEC. 3. INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS AUTHORIZED FOR ALL BUSINESSES. Section 2 of Public Law 93-100 (12 U.S.C. 1832) is amended to allow depository institutions to permit owners of interest-bearing accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account within the same institution. This new provision categorizes such accounts as transaction accounts unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with regulations set by the Board for payment and distribution of earnings. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with regulations set by the Board for payment and distribution of earnings. Depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility have responsibilities for crediting and distributing earnings from balances maintained in a Federal reserve bank. The term 'depository institution' is defined for this purpose. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include various institutions such as trust companies, corporations under section 25A, and branches of foreign banks. Section 19(c)(1)(B) is amended to remove the exclusion of non-member banks. Section 1002 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is revised for consumer banking costs assessment. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include various institutions such as trust companies, corporations under section 25A, and branches of foreign banks. Section 19(c)(1)(B) is amended to remove the exclusion of non-member banks. Section 1002 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is revised for consumer banking costs assessment. The Federal Reserve System must conduct an annual survey to gather data on retail banking services and products offered by insured depository institutions and credit unions, including checking accounts, savings accounts, ATM transactions, and electronic transactions. The survey must be representative of different types and sizes of institutions, as well as geographic locations. The Federal Reserve System conducts an annual survey to gather data on retail banking services, including details on checking and transaction accounts such as fees, minimum balances, check processing fees, and availability of low-cost accounts for consumers with low balances. The data collected on negotiable order of withdrawal accounts and savings accounts includes monthly and annual fees, minimum balances, interest rates, check processing fees, fees for using tellers, and availability of low-cost accounts for consumers with low balances. Automated teller machine transactions data includes monthly and annual fees, and card fees. The data on electronic transactions includes fees for withdrawals, deposits, balance inquiries, wire transfers, and payments made over the Internet or through other electronic means. The Federal Reserve may collect data on fees and charges deemed necessary, and has the authority to cease collection if no longer needed. An annual report to Congress on the results is required. The Federal Reserve will prepare a report on survey results regarding retail banking services, including trends in cost and availability nationwide, in 50 representative states, and in each metropolitan statistical area. The Federal Reserve will submit an annual report to Congress on retail banking services, detailing differences between institutions based on type, size, and multistate activity. Despite certain provisions, the Board will continue to comply with bank fee survey requirements on an interim basis. The Federal Reserve will submit an annual report to Congress on retail banking services, detailing differences between institutions based on type, size, and multistate activity. The report will include information on credit card fees and charges, even if not required by law. Definitions for "insured depository institution" and "insured credit union" are provided. Additionally, an amendment to the Truth in Lending Act is mentioned. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to require the Board to collect credit card price and availability information from financial institutions semiannually. This includes disclosure information, average finance charges, and details on application fees, annual percentage rates for cash advances and balance transfers, and maximum rates for default accounts. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to collect credit card price and availability information from financial institutions semiannually, including details on fees for convenience checks, balance transfers, and foreign currency conversions. The effective date for the amendment is January 1, 2003, and a sunset provision in the Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994 is repealed. Additionally, a provision in the Federal Reports Elimination and Sunset Act of 1995 does not apply to reports required under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989. The Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 made technical and conforming amendments to the Federal Reserve Act, specifically in subsections (b)(4) and (c)(1)(A). SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to give the Federal Reserve Board more flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 deals with the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow the Federal Reserve banks to determine the amount each bank shall pay for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Additionally, no Federal reserve bank may replenish its surplus fund with any transfer made under this provision during the specified fiscal years. During fiscal years 2002 through 2006, any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of Federal Reserve banks will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund. SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. In connection with a real estate transaction, an escrow account at a depository institution may have certain expenses absorbed, fees waived, or benefits provided without being considered as interest payment. This exemption applies to various banking functions and is not subject to interest payment regulations under specific laws. The curr_chunk discusses interest payment regulations at depository institutions. The curr_chunk states that the bill was passed by the House of Representatives on April 9, 2002, with the attestation of Jeff Trandahl, the Clerk.
